“How,” we wonder with Allen (2016), can “critical theory be truly critical if it remains committed to an imperialist meta narrative, that is, if it has not yet been decolonized?”

Allen (2016) explains that Said (1993) was arguing that this silence grew from critical theory’s complicity in (European) culture and (European) imperialism (the title of Said’s book is Culture and Imperialism ).

In the next section we wend our critique of critical methods to the decolonial critique of critical theory proffered by, among others, philosopher Amy Allen (2016) and Ndlovu-Ghatsheni (Ndlovu-Gatsheni, 2018; Ndlovu-Gatsheni, 2018, 2021).

In The End of Progress: Decolonizing the Normative Foundations of Critical Theory , Amy Allen (2016) both expands on and attempts to think through Edward Said’s criticism of Frankfurt School critical theory for its stunning “silence on racist theory, anti-imperialist resistance, and opposition practice to empires” (p. 278).

Moreover, Allen (2016) shows that Jürgen Habermas and Axel Honneth, two of critical theory’s most prominent proponents, grounded their concerns for power, inequality, and social change in concepts that extended from the Eurocentric metanarrative of human progress.

citations.title: Critical theory and North American indigenous thought
contexts: In addition to Adorno and Foucault, Allen praises Anthony Laden ’ s contemporary critical theory for exemplifying a decolonized approach.

Allen recommends returning to ﬁ rst-generation Frankfurter Theodor Adorno and his “ other son ” Michel Foucault, who she argues offer critical resources that are not dependent on Eurocentric ideas of progress.
To those two, “ life under modern capitalism is so deformed and distorted that moral philosophy today cannot provide plans or blue-prints for living the good life ” (Allen, 2016: 196).

Instead, Allen writes, quoting Adorno, the “ most one could say about the good life under current conditions is that it ‘ would consist in resistance to the forms of the bad life that have been seen through and critically dissected by the most progressive minds ’” (Allen, 2016: 196).
In addition to endorsing Adorno ’ s account of the good life as resistance to the current bad, Allen also cites his claim that “ progress occurs where it ends ” (Allen, 2016: 198).

“ Reasoning well demands a particular set of virtues, ” Allen explains, “ not only a willingness to make oneself vulnerable and an openness to change, but also a ‘ receptivity to unfamiliar lines of criticism ’” (Laden, 2012: 129; Allen, 2016: 223).

Citing James Tully ’ s critique of neo-Kantianism, she diagnoses Forst ’ s project as neo-imperialistic because it involves extending that Kantian tradition of ethics into cultural traditions that do not have it (Allen, 2016: 138; Tully, 2008).
Critical theorists maintain that this does not make them relativists, as Allen repeatedly insists (Allen, 2016: 224).

For Allen, the solution to contemporary critical theory ’ s vestiges of Hegelian and Kantian colonialism is to return to an earlier form of it, which she locates in the work of Adorno and his “ other son ” Foucault (Allen, 2016: 187).

Adorno and Foucault offer a form of critical theorizing that, rather than claiming normative grounds rooted in Eurocentrism, instead focuses on theorizing as “ problematizing our historical present ” (190).

In detailed analyses, Allen shows how Honneth and Habermas both presume their normative standards (intersubject-ive communication for Habermas, a form of freedom for Honneth) are a product of af ﬁ rming historical development (Allen, 2016: 66, 92).
Among those virtues Allen numbers “ vulnerability, openness, and receptivity ” (Allen, 2016: 223).

…in the world outside of human society implies a kind of transcendence of historical situations (as Coulthard puts it, “ spirituality outside of historical time ” ) that is troublesome for critical theorists who af ﬁ rm Hegel ’ s account of the historicity of understanding (Allen, 2016: 217).
Nichols explicitly describes his book as a “ contribution to critical theory ” (Nichols, 2020: 10), and Allen implies much the same thing (Allen, 2016: xii).
In part of her endorsement of Adorno and Foucault ’ s decolonial substance, she says critical theory is at its best when it does not offer a deep positive vision of the good life.

To Allen, Habermas and Honneth rest their normative foundations on this concept of progress, which she considers a left-Hegelian approach (Allen, 2016: 3) not entirely dissimilar to the Classical Marxism that is a non-starter for many Indigenous peoples (Churchill, 1983; Habermas, 1996; Honneth,…

She praises Adorno and Foucault for refusing to consider the “ right life ” as a positive concept, with them only prescribing “ resistance to the forms of the bad life that have been seen through and critically dissected by the most progressive minds.

Critical theorists have long been sympathetic to the struggles of Indigenous peoples, yet some have recently noticed that much of contemporary critical theory is suffused with assumptions that limit its ability to understand or endorse Indigenous claims (Allen, 2016; Nichols, 2020).
